title: Geeetech G2S hall effect end stop adaptor

description.text:
This is my variation of the standard axis end stop fitting for the Geeetech G2S that allows the fitting of hall effect end stops. I am upgrading my printer to a Radds controller so want to use the better end stops. All of the other versions I have seen involve gluing the magnets to the top of the the carriage thus removing any mechanical adjustment.
I made this with holder to screw onto the original adjuster screw and then glued the magnet into this, then the other part just replaces the the acrylic part that holds the old end stop. It is made so the end stops sold with the Radds controller lines up with the adjuster screw.
When I can I will upload pics of it fitted but it is all lined up and working.

G2S Delta

title: FPV Ground recording station for Connex HD, Mini and Prosight

description.text:
When the new Connex HD FPV system for small quads and racing drones comes out, the Connex Prosight, there is no onboard recording facility as a non-recording factory supplied camera is used. As it is a lossless HD downlink this need not be a problem as the footage can be recorded on the ground. I used a Hauppage Rocket PVR which compares very well with the cheaper "Gameboy" HD recorders. It is a bit more expensive but works well with the Connex. I have tried it on the full HD system and it works well and there is no reason it should not work with the Mini or Prosight when it comes out.

The printed box can be mounted on the tripod as shown and simply serves to tidy the cables and batteries etc. which otherwise would form a tangled heap on the ground. I clamped mine to the side of the tripod but if there is any need I will design another to use the camera mount of the tripod.

Once set up all that is required to record is to hit the big red button!

comments.text:
Printed it at 50% scale for surface mount electronic components using Flashforge Creator Pro with PLC filament.
Printbed covered with blue painters tape at room temperature (not heated at all).
Extruder at 225 deg C.
No rafts needed as it has good surface adhesion. Rafts actually are difficult to snap off if used as the surfaces are too big (I discovered as the box was ticked in Makerbot on my first print - luckily it was a drawer).

title: "The pit stop" stone fruit pit removal

description.text: Will remove even the toughest pits of just about every stone fruit. Insert into fruit at stem and drive all the way through. Pull out the core. Remove core from tool by gently pushing rod and pulling back on the wings. Enjoy your whole pitless fruit with minimal damage/bruising. Design made for class for Bio Resource and Agricultural Engineering class at California Polytechnic University of San Luis Obispo.
Print all three parts. Take the rod and insert it into the main cylindrical part. Then carefully insert tapered wedge through main part, through the cylinder, and out the other end.

This is my remix of the Micro 105 quadcopter using the same Micro Scisky controller and 8.5mm Hubsan motors, all parts sourced from GearBest

8.5mm Hubsan motors from GearBest http://www.gearbest.com/rc-quadcopter-parts/pp_354806.html

Power leads from GearBest http://www.gearbest.com/multi-rotor-parts/pp_260798.html
Batteries and charger from GearBest http://www.gearbest.com/rc-quadcopter-parts/pp_270382.html

23/6/16 Added a version 3 body with more motor support
26/7/16 Added a version for 8mm motors
31/8/16 Added a version 4 with even more motor support
02/09/16 Added a new 8mm motor body with more motor support, deleted older versions with less motor support as they generally don't hold the motors in too well after a crash.
Added an alternative top plate for non FPV builds that can be fitted with nylon pillars and screws.

title: Bowden Filament Guide for RepRapPro Mendel

description.text: Some of the best solutions are simple, but there is something to be said for the over-engineered ones. This is filament guide featuring a Bowden tube and BSP Connectors for super smooth  reliable filament delivery!

I Have been using this great spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17473) on top of my Mendel. It works great except for the 180 degree bend the filament needs to travel to get from the spool to the intake of the filament drive. Due to the weight of the spool when the filament drive was extruding, the slack in the filament was taken up and would get jammed. I tried many solutions including a couple of guides here on thingiverse. None of which particularly worked. So i made a mash up. As well as the printed parts you will need: 2 x 1/8" BSP Push connectors
1 x 20cm PTFE Tube 4mm OD, 2mm ID (for 1.75mm Filament)
4 x m3 screws and nuts Its fairly obvious how to put it together and it works a charm. I havent had any jams since!

description.text:
I'm building a printer that uses cables to keep the bed level. in order to do so, I need to manage the tension on the cables. this worm-gear box design is based on how a guitar tunes the tension on its strings.

to use, screw the box onto your frame, place the end of the cable through the large slot on the centre cog, and use the screw-driver slots on the side of the box to pull the cable around the cog.

customized with 3D Slash!

This is an 80mm IoT field mill. The field mill is usually located outside, a few feet above the ground and pointing towards the ground, where it measures the local E-field strength and polarity. This field mill has a place for a NodeMCU module that sends out the E-field measurements wirelessly.

The non-3D parts needed to complete the field mill are some 3mm heat set inserts, 3mm screws, 4-40x1/4" set screws, 4-40 jam nut, 5mm shaft, 5x16x5 bearing, motor, flex tubing, copper foil tape, custom circuit board, NodeMCU module, and a printed label for the optical encoder.

The rotor is covered with self adhesive copper foil tape. A 4-40 x 1/4" set screw with a 4-40 jam nut on top holds the rotor in place and electrically connects the foil to the shaft. The 5mm shaft must be grounded; I used a repurposed motor brush as a contactor to the shaft. The faceplate and frame are bonded together to form one piece. I used ABS for these parts and solvent bonded them together. More copper foil tape goes on the faceplate sensor areas and is soldered to wires fed through the faceplate. The encoder wheel needs to be drilled out to 5mm for the shaft, and all set screw holes tapped for 4-40 threads. The motor shaft is about 2mm diameter, so a shaft adapter is used to bring it up to about 5mm and then a bit of flexible tubing is used as a shaft coupler.

title: Oculus Rift CV1 Prescription Lens Adapter

description.text:
This adapter for the Oculus Rift is designed to position prescription eyeglass lenses just above the fresnel lenses of the Rift headset. The prescription lenses that fit this adapter are available by ordering eyeglasses from Zenni optical with frame #550021.

This adapter is the result of a few weeks of design in Autodesk Inventor and tweaking to get it working for my face, then a total redesign using Autodesk Fusion 360. This was my first fully realized 3d design and 3d printing project, so while a lot of people have successfully used this adapter, I make no guarantees that this adapter will work for anyone but me! To make for easier remixes, this design is also available in it's native Fusion 360 format here: http://a360.co/2g4JcHj

To use:
Once you have the glasses from Zenni, you need to remove the lenses from the frame, but before you do, make some small orientation marks with a marker on the edge of the lens so you know which way is up and which lens is right and left. You want to maintain the correct orientation when transferring the lenses to the adapter.

With the lenses out of the Zenni frame, you should fit the lenses into the groove in the inner rim of the adapter. Outside of the Rift headset the lenses will fit somewhat loosely in the adapter. Once the adapter is fit onto the headset the tension on the adapter will make the lenses more secure.

There are tabs at the bottom of the adapter that should straddle the plastic rim at the bottom of the facial interface.

The top curved part should be oriented so its sitting flush against the indentation on the facial interface that gives clearance for the cord.

Once the adapter with lenses is fit in the facial interface, re-attach the assembly to the rift by pushing in the flat tab at the top, then gently fit the bottom tabs into place.

Edit 18/1/15:
Replaced the main file with a new file that is correctly manifold.
Added an in-progress version that is designed for the lenses to snap into place. (I like this version because the lenses are solid even when the adapter is removed. Makes it easier to pull the adapter out to demo the rift. I still like the old version too because it has more clearance around the nose area.)

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm works fine. .1 is slightly better

Infill:

20%+

comments.text:
Hi,
Design looks great! Two questions: Do you remove the facial interface, and then put the lenses in, and then replace in the Rift? And... I kinda forgot to mark the lens orientation. Whoops!
comments.author: mcm001

comments.text: Remove the interface from the rift, put the lenses in the adapter, fit the adapter on the interface and hold it in place as you put the interface back onto the rift. If you don't have the lens orientation marked it shouldn't be too bad to figure out the right orientation. The lenses aren't true round, they are slightly oblong, so there's only two orientations per lens that fits the adapter as it should. You should be able to put the lens into the adapter and rotate it to see where it fits the best. Once you have that figured out look through the lenses with the adapter in the interface but not in the rift to figure out which orientation looks correct.
comments.author: mcm001

comments.text: Having some issues with the fit on these, I printed them at .1mm layer height, and they are virtually perfect, lenses snap in great. The problem is, after being fitted into the facial interface it doesn't really snap into place. The middle bridge section seems to be extruded out too far and keeps the top from being fully flush, which leads to gaps around the visor all around. I sanded and filed it down a bit as I'm also using a Widmo VR cover, but those elastic straps are quite thin and even without the cover it still pushes out the interface when lenses are in place.

comments.text: The lenses in the zenni frame turned out to be slightly oblong, and the design matches that. So will it fit fully circular 43mm lenses? Maybe. The lenses would probably fit, but not seat perfectly. If you wanted, you could take the fusion 360 file and make it fit a fully circular lens. The model is parametric enough for that change to be fairly easy to do. As to PD, the adapter matches the Zenni frame dimensions, so if you don't use lenses from that frame you'd have to figure out lens PD as appropriate for whatever lenses you're getting.

I had him make three since I thought I might need to cut & glue a couple together to compensate for pupil distance. Pulled my glasses out of the envelope from Zenni Optical an hour ago (Friday - I'd also ordered on Monday) and thought they were a bit wide, but after bending the nose pads in & slapping them on my face it seems a perfect prescription. I then took them off and lined them up to one of the prints -- spacing on the frames and the adapter print appear identical, and I anticipate not having to cram the Oculus slider adjustment to the extreme left anymore. A VERY tiny Phillips driver is req'd for loosening the frames to pop out the lenses. Now I'm looking for a [email protected]*ed Sharpie so I can 'index' them before removing and transferring to the adapter...will update...

comments.text: One question.  Zenni Optical wants to know my PD (pupillary distance).  When my prescription lenses are transferred to the adapter, how much will this value change?  There must be some margin of error, right?
comments.author: samsonite1

comments.text: You should be ordering the glasses using your prescription ipd.  The adapter lens spacing matches the zenni frame lens spacing.
comments.author: samsonite1

comments.text: My prescription didn't come with that info.  I was thinking about using the adjustable IPD value of the headset for reference.  From what I can measure with a ruler and piece of paper, it's almost the same.  But if I'm off by 3 mm, I hope it won't affect my vision.
comments.author: jegstad

comments.text: I used the IPD from the Oculus settings and it was fine. I think Zenni just wants to make sure the frames will fit your face, but you will throw them away anyway.
comments.author: samsonite1

comments.text: Ah, so you're saying the IPD value is not used in the manufacturing of the lenses?  It's only for the frames?   That seems to make sense.
comments.author: fulg

comments.text:
IPD is used in conjunction with the frame size/spacing to determine where the lens maker puts the optical center of the lens.
http://www.zennioptical.com/blog/what-is-pd-and-why-is-it-important/
https://endmyopia.org/how-to-measure-pd-pupillary-distance/
"If you have a low myopia prescription, and no astigmatism correction, getting PD exactly right isn’t that big of a deal. Of course you don’t want to blindly guess at it, but a millimeter or two either way won’t affect your lens wear notably.
So if that’s you, you’re in the clear.
But if you have a high myopia prescription, and especially if you also have an astigmatism correction, the PD suddenly becomes pretty important. "
comments.author: samsonite1

comments.text: Technically speaking, how is the "optical center" added to the lens?  Is the lens material physically and/or permanently altered or is it something to do with the film coating?
comments.author: jegstad

comments.text:
It's defined during the grinding of a prescription lens. There's plenty of references about this stuff on the internet, but I thought this reference explains it pretty well (#7 on the page):
https://books.google.com/books?id=_Z15AAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA122&ots=oeBGed7LsN&dq=prescription%20lens%20how%20its%20made%20%22optical%20center%22&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q&f=false
comments.author: samsonite1

comments.text: Ah, so the edges of the lens are grinded down to move the marked optical center to center of your eye.  It does matter.  A whole lot.

comments.text: The lenses in the adapter should not contact the headset lenses unless you are pressing on the adapter lenses or something.  Picture 3 shows the spacing between the adapter and the headset lenses.  The lenses pictured are 1.57 index lenses with a medium strength prescription (-6 diopters).  I don't know how much thicker a stronger prescription would make the lense, but there is a few mm of clearance with my lenses.  As I understand it, higher index lenses would be thinner/flatter.

comments.text: Hi there. I have a small question. In this model, What is the distance  between lens（front asphere） and eyes ? The front asphere of regular eyeglasses should be 15mm far from eyes. Every mm dose the matter, especially for the high index glasses. From your picture ,It looks like this frame is 3~5mm farther than the regular glasses. Im sure that if the distance miss matched ,  it will miss match the asphere curve and cause the slightly blur.
comments.author: Insonia

comments.text: Since the adapters affixes lenses to the headset, the distance of the lenses from your eyes will be a function of how the cv1 fits on your particular face.  How far are the cv1 lenses from your eyes now?  Take that distance and subtract 4 mm and you'll have a rough guess at how far the adapter lenses will be from your eyes.
comments.author: Insonia

comments.text:
Thanks for the replay.
The CV1 lens are fresnel lens. The light through lens is almost collimated. Only the FOV changes by the distance. It just need align the center with your pupils. But prescription lens are distance-sensitive. It is a function of each particular eye only. It should stay near that place. The higher index of glass and higher myopia the more sensitive it is.The foam is soft but the frame is still solid. Actually its still lot space . But It too hard to measure inside that space.

title: Nay Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Nay lamp is a product designed by me and created in the LABoral FabLab Gijon, Spain. It consists of 35 pieces that are assembled on both upper and lower circles making the lamp has an oval shape. It consists of two colors, white and black, to light and shade effects on space. It may be a ceiling lamp or table. I hope you like it.

The construction of this lamp is made by assembling the pieces on the two circles bases. The inner rectangle gives the height of the lamp is assembled on itself to create a cylinder. It has two tabs above and two below to join the circles, but I recommend that if someone wants to make this design placed in the file other two tabs above and below so that the subject is more accurate.
I also recommend that you change the slots in the box making them smaller so that the cylinder is more accurately grasp.
I hope you liked this design and I like it if someone does consider these tips to avoid problems in the assembly of the lamp.

description.text: This is a antenna mount for the impulse rc alien 5" frame. It mounts to the rear set of mid frame posts. Ideally it is intended to keep the antennas closer to the center of the frame so that when you fly with a lot of camera angle your antennas are not flying way above the back of the frame. Works well for me, and gives the alien a cool look also imo. Give me feedback it you think changes should be made. Cheers

Printer:

Creator pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed in PLA on my bed in the upside down position. All tolerances for shrinkage are set for PLA so it may not print the same in ABS.

comments.text: I really like this design. It's very organic looking. I put one on a Drone Works Gremlin frame. The stand-offs are closer together and have wider upper and lower areas so I had to modify it slightly. I scaled it to 112%, then cut the end of the tubes down so it was 35mm tall, and used Slic3r to cut the model in half width-wise, then remove enough material that each side was 22.5mm wide. Finally, I placed them so that they touched each other on the bed in Slic3r and it output the two pieces merged together. Printed and it fit perfectly.

Esporte Clube Vitória, usually known simply as Vitória, is a Brazilian football team from Salvador in Bahia, founded on May 13, 1899. The team plays in the Campeonato Brasileiro Série A and the Campeonato Baiano, respectively top divisions of national and state football.

Vitória's home games are played at the club's own stadium, Manoel Barradas, capacity 35,632. The team plays in red and black horizontal striped shirts, black shorts and black socks. The stripes have changed over time: they have been sometimes vertical, horizontal, wide and narrow.

This is yet another, under desktop-headphone hanger thing.
I made this as I'd like the clip to grip the desk instead of just sitting there. It should fit tables a little thicker than 22cm depending on the material. I also made it long enough to fit my headset which has a 40cm wide headband. To save plastic I placed "tear-drop" shaped holes. The reason to not go for simple holes is that this way, the printer won't have to do anymore than 45° overhang. Oh and it's also sorta repraps logo :P Since I wanted this done quickly, I made it in inventor pro, so no sourcefiles for any other than that :/ sry. If you want me to try and do it in openSCAD shoot me a comment and I'll try if I feel like it.

1) Print it.
2) Clip it on your table
3) slide headphones on
4) ....
5) Profit (not really)

title: EDGE X 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is EDGE X, a compact, low cost 3D printer. It has a few new features... Coming to instructables soon.

-Update - May 1st 2017- This project has NOT been abandoned. Far from it. I just updated the .svg file and main image. The Edge X line will go along side of the Edge V line, V4 will probably be published this summer if I'm ambitious enough, or next spring. This currently has my focus. -Hint: V4 will have smooth linear rods on both sides of z axis. It only costs $4 more and if it is broke without it, it's worth it.-

This printer (5 of them, plus a 3.0) will be presented at Vancouver Maker Faire on June 10 and 11th at the Edge 3D Printers booth.

The new features are: auto-levelling, newer MK8 extruder (spring/lever for easy filament swapping), larger build area despite smaller footprint, no z-wobble (still working on bolting method for z bearings, currently friction-fit; reason of minor wobble. Just being honest.), and a design that subjectively looks better.

title: Miniature Painting Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: I suggest this remake: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2035825 instead, it is a much better concept than mine and allows for larger miniature height!

Based off the one I saw here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:354125 I rebuilt it from scratch.

In short this allows you to hold and position a miniature easily while painting. This is a 25mm base for scale.

I have shared this under a non-commercial license. But I grant anyone the right to sell this as long as they inform me they are selling it. :)

UPDATES: I added a glue-down-plate that you can stick a miniature to if you don't want to use one of my custom bases. The "Y" slot will allow you to more easily pop it off when done. I also made it slightly larger than the other diameters and knurled so the miniature on top of it can be rotated without touching it. Plus you can put this under a base and "stack" the plates. I also added a larger protective arm to accommodate this wider plate.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm layers, 0.35mm nozzle

Infill:

15%

Notes:

These are the settings I used, your mileage might vary.

Assembly

Print one of each piece. Note that the "magnet miniature base" is meant to be glued to the bottom of your miniature with the hole down. Color it accordingly. If you don't want to put a base on your miniature ignore the "magnet" parts and just glue a miniature to the base unit. Or design your own holder base and use that.

The Base Unit gets flipped over with the open end down.
The arm gets put in the slot and glued.
The magnet plate gets put on top (clean side to clean side)
NOTE: I made this plate separate so different plates could be printed for different miniature base types without completely reinventing the holder. IE. You wouldn't want to use magnets with warhammer, etc.
The hole in the top of the magnet stand gets 1 10mmx1mm round magnets glued into it. Or one 10mmx2mm magnet.
The magnet miniature base also gets magnets glued into it (Make sure the polarity of the magnets matches before gluing) and gets glued to the bottom of your miniature.

You can now attach the magnets and the miniature should hold.

Enjoy!

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

I set my daughter up with a new art workstation, but she's got limited space and I didn't want her desk to be cluttered up with all of her art supplies. A pegboard seemed like a great solution, but all of the regular pegboard stuff I find is intended to hold more traditional workshop tools, and not really designed for holding art supplies like brushes, colored pencils, and paints.

This is a variety of different types of boxes and bins, and a wide shelf, intended to hold the sort of thing she needed held. If they were useful to me, I figured they could be useful to someone else too.

All of the notches in the vectors are designed with 1/8th inch thick plywood in mind (so .125in which is fairly equivalent to 3mm thick plywood if your source is metric)

The vectors are organized so you can understand and identify the parts for all of the different box types. They are not laid out in an optimized arrangement for materials use. Whatever size your material is, you'll want to rearrange the pieces so that they fit your space with the least wasted space.

If you want some of these guys, but don't have a lasercutter of your own, I'm totally game for cutting the parts and shipping them, or going all the way to assembling and shipping things. I can even customize the sizes and shapes of things for you. You can message me on etsy through my shop here -
https://www.etsy.com/shop/GameVetz

title: Lulzbot Mini Camera Mount (Y-mounted) for time lapse video

description.text:
This is a camera mount I built for my Lulzbot Mini to use with the time lapse feature in OctoPrint. It slides right onto the corner of the Y axis build plate. The three grooves are for where the screws extend through the aluminum plate under the leveling disc and corner damper. They assist in keeping the mount oriented and secured to the bed. I recommend using a little electrical tape placed right on top of the 3 protruding screws on the aluminum plate. This helps dampen any rapid movements and keeps those vibrations from slightly shifting the camera over longer prints.

The camera connector can be altered to fit your own camera design, that is up to you.

The screw is for adjusting the height of the camera view for larger prints. Another option would be to use a fisheye camera lens.

After testing, I decided to make the mount longer to place the camera farther away. In doing so, it became too tall for the Mini to print, so I chopped off a little at the top. It would be kind of silly to make a camera mount for the Lulzbot Mini which it is unable to print, now wouldn't it?

NO SUPPORTS!

Example video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pd3l7CYgHR0&feature=youtu.be

Enjoy!

title: Small Simple Letter Scale (Range: 0~10g) - Fully printable!

description.text:
This simple letter scale can weight between 0 and about 10g.
I wanted to design a scale that can quickly be printed and uses few resources. It required about 2 m of filament at the original scale.
The scale was designed in Catia. Hope you guys like it. Good luck assembling and have fun!

Download all the parts, or the zip containing all parts. The number of times each part has to be printed is indicated in the filename. The scale is designed that it can be assembled completely from the 3d printed parts and some 1.75mm filament. So no parts are needed that aren't already in the house To connect the pieces sandwich the base and the counterweights between the L shaped measuring arm and the hanger. Then push some filament trough the joints and melt the ends with a soldering iron. To make the scale ready for use attach some counterweight on the plate at the bottom of the base with some tape. Then the scale needs to be calibrated. To calibrate the scale use some coins and attach them to the plates attached at each end of the lever. Since the weight of the coins is known, one can calculate a simple formula to relate the angle at which the lever balances to the weight that is attached.
I am using a 5ct euro coint as counterweight. It weighs 3.9g. Using some math and experimentation I found, that the weight to be measured can be described by the following formula: tan(x) * 8.05 = measured weight in g with x being the angle of the lever. This should be a good starting point for calibration. Attach several different weights and note their angle. Then you can solve the equation above for the factor on the left side (8.05). If you do this for a range of different known weights (for example different coins) you can then average those factors to get an accurate relation. The scale reaches an accuracy of about +- 0.1g. I want to design a printable scale in the near future, however most likely the exact factor will change from print to print, therefore the scales will vary and be inaccurate. Therefore use scales from other people with caution. Take a look at the pictures for reference, and feel free to ask any questions below.

comments.text:
3D Printing Newbie - Having problems with the quality of the finish to the 'blade' of the cookie cutter. The result is a bit 'stringy' with gaps between layers in places.
Have tried printing with ABS and PLA with similar results. Tried increasing temp to aid layer bonding, higher resolution, more shells (doubt this effects something as thin as this), and more infill - but this made little improvement. Any advice?
comments.author: RavingMunster

comments.text:
Ideally, you should print with just one shell. the blade should be as thin as possible.
I have made a few modifications and uploaded it as a new file: The new one is solid and you should print it with 0% infill, 1 shell and without top and bottom.
comments.author: RavingMunster

comments.text: At first I didn't realize why you painted these. The Hakko uses infrared light to detect the key. If these are printed out of PLA the ir will shine right through them and the key will never be detected. I printed some with ABS and they work without paint.
comments.author: bjr9979

comments.text: Yep, and if your printer prints without gaps you can maybe get lucky and not paint them, but they are much more reliable with a little coat of acrylic paint.  Thanks for the data on ABS!
